skill.name: agent-swarm-workflow
skill.description: Jeffrey Emanuel's multi-agent implementation workflow using NTM, Agent Mail, Beads, and BV. The execution phase that follows planning and bead creation. Includes exact prompts used.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing workflow prompts. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access patterns. Pure prompt-based documentation for multi-agent coordination.

content.value_statement: Managing multiple AI agents working in parallel requires careful coordination and clear workflows. This skill provides exact prompts and proven patterns for running coordinated agent swarms that avoid conflicts and maximize throughput.
actual_capabilities: Spawn multiple AI agents in tmux sessions using NTM
Coordinate agent work through Agent Mail with file reservations
Prioritize tasks using BV tool with robot flags
Use exact prompts for agent marching orders and next-bead selection
Implement quality review loops with self-review and cross-review prompts
Handle context compaction with recovery prompts
limitations: Requires pre-configured AGENTS.md with tool definitions
Requires running Agent Mail server (am or mcp_agent_mail)
Requires NTM tool for session management
Requires BV tool for task selection and bead management

use_cases.title: Scale Code Delivery
use_cases.description: Coordinate multiple AI agents to parallelize feature development across large codebases with conflict-free file access.

use_cases.title: Automate Infrastructure
use_cases.description: Deploy multiple agents to work on infrastructure tasks simultaneously while maintaining coordination and avoiding merge conflicts.

use_cases.title: Multi-Model Research
use_cases.description: Combine Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini agents in a single swarm to leverage different model strengths on complex problems.

prompt_templates.title: Initial Marching Orders
prompt_templates.prompt: First read AGENTS.md and README.md. Use code investigation mode to understand the project architecture. Register with MCP Agent Mail and introduce yourself to other agents.

prompt_templates.title: Move to Next Bead
prompt_templates.prompt: Reread AGENTS.md. Use bv with robot flags to find the highest-impact bead you can work on now. Start coding immediately and communicate your work to fellow agents.

prompt_templates.title: Self-Review Code
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the code you just wrote with fresh eyes looking for bugs, errors, and problems. Fix anything you uncover. Repeat until no issues found.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-Agent Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review code written by other agents. Check for bugs, security issues, inefficiencies, and reliability problems. Diagnose root causes and fix if needed.

output_examples.input: Run the initial marching orders prompt on a new swarm session
output: Agent registers with Agent Mail server
Agent announces itself to all active agents
Agent uses bv to find highest-priority ready bead
Agent reserves files for exclusive access
Agent announces work starting to other agents

best_practices: Start with a comprehensive plan and polished beads from the planning and beads workflow skills
Use BV robot flags (--robot-triage, --robot-next) for automated task selection
Keep agents moving to avoid communication purgatory where nothing gets done
anti_patterns: Running bare 'bv' command which launches blocking TUI
Skipping the self-review phase after each bead completion
Not having AGENTS.md configured with all tool definitions before starting

faq.question: Which AI models work in the swarm?
faq.answer: Claude Code (Opus recommended), Codex (GPT 5.2), and Gemini. A mix of different models leverages their different strengths.

faq.question: How many agents should I run at once?
faq.answer: Start with 3-6 agents. More agents means faster execution but higher coordination overhead between agents.

faq.question: How do agents avoid editing the same files?
faq.answer: Agents use file reservations through Agent Mail. Exclusive reservations block other agents from editing the same files.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only provides prompts. No data leaves your system. Agents run locally with your existing tool configurations.

faq.question: What happens if an agent crashes?
faq.answer: Every agent is fungible and a generalist. Simply start a new session and the replacement agent reads AGENTS.md to continue.

faq.question: How is this different from other agent workflows?
faq.answer: This workflow uses fungible agents (no specialization), BV for automated prioritization, and Agent Mail for coordination instead of central planning.
